reviews.text: Although there's some variety in enemies and environments, a lot of Babylon's Fall feels the same, making it a bit repetitive over time.
Combat is the main focus in Babylon's Fall as there isn't much else to the game than fighting hordes of enemies through similarly laid out levels.
the problem with using elemental damage comes with the inability to craft anything at this point in the game.
the rewards of completing Babylon's Fall aren't worth the effort of going through the unbearably repetitive gameplay.
the oil-paint art style of the game makes it difficult to distinguish anything in combat, especially in the darker levels.
the platforming challenges are a way to break up the constant combat, but with not much difference between levels, it's hard to avoid repetition.
the Battle Pass progression is extremely slow... most rewards are more easily obtained from other activities.
combat feels like a long sequence of button-mashing for the sake of progression.
the only way to test weapon combinations is by starting a quest, causing backtracking or abandoning quests if the loadout is ineffective.
missions and orders require replaying levels, leading to grinding.
the campaign is a string of indiscernible combat encounters with a few big boss fights.
three Sentinel factions to choose from at the start of Babylon's Fall. Huysian Sentinels start with a sword, Agavian have a hammer, and Geleilion use a bow. All can use any weapons later.
Gideon Coffins can change or kill the host if they aren't strong enough.
the Volcanic Cloister introduces elemental damage susceptibilities but crafting is impossible early in the game
the only way to test weapon combinations is by starting a quest, causing backtracking or abandoning quests if the loadout is ineffective
the oil-paint art style makes it hard to distinguish enemies in darker levels
missions and orders require replaying levels, leading to grinding
the Battle Pass's rewards are mostly cosmetic and easily obtained elsewhere
the campaign is a string of indiscernible combat encounters with few unique environments
the Gideon Coffin system's spectral attacks add variety but are hampered by poor visual clarity
